properties.short_description: Making your jump line dreams come true

long_description.what: Hone your skills on medium and large rails and boxes, and five aptly spaced jumps ranging from 30 to 50 feet. Get those new tricks dialed, or perfect the ones you've got.

properties.name: Dream Maker

properties.short_description: Imagine your favorite natural terrain gully, but groomed and enhanced with minimal to moderate shaping

long_description.what: A low level family race track of mellow banked slalom turns to tame cross course features and built on a gentle enough pitch to prevent excess speed
long_description.who: For the whole family to enjoy together
long_description.when: You're looking for a fun, mellow family shred sesh

properties.name: Family Cross

properties.short_description: The little brother of Bear Mountain’s The Stash

long_description.what: Like Woodward Progression Parks, this is where freestyle newbies can cut their teeth before stepping up to the larger park zones
long_description.when: You want to get back to nature, but aren't quite ready for big features

properties.name: Lil' Stash on Lower Easy Street

properties.short_description: Founded by Danny Davis and designed to encourage creative expression, Peace Park is for the people.

long_description.what: Woodward Peace Park transcends standard slopestyle and halfpipes, has more flow, transition and room to breathe. Snow shredders on snowboards and skis are all welcome. Peace Park was founded in 2011 by Danny Davis, a Grand Prix Winner, X Games Gold Medalist, Dew Tour Champion, and a U.S. Olympic Snowboard athlete. Danny created Peace Park to be a new type of on-mountain experience that reinvents freestyle terrain with a focus on fun and flow.
long_description.when: You don't want to go huge, you just want to have fun with your crew

properties.name: Peace Park on Timberline

properties.short_description: It pops up early season and sticks around until we have enough snow to bring most of the other parks online

long_description.what: A handful of jumps, rails and whatever jibs the crew feels like sticking in the snow
long_description.when: The season is still young and you're looking to hit features of varying sizes

properties.name: Pop Up Park on Mouse Run

properties.short_description: It pops up early season and sticks around until we have enough snow to bring most of the other parks online

long_description.what: Typically debuts on the first day of the season with a rail set up that'll get your legs back in no time
long_description.where: Reason up on the North Ridge
long_description.when: You want to get back in the park as soon as the season starts

properties.name: Pop Up Park on Reason

properties.short_description: It pops up late season for spring jibbing once our other parks have closed for the season

long_description.what: Typically debuts middle to late April with a few features to keep you jibbing until the snow melts
long_description.where: Skye Hawk, serviced by the Superstar Express Quad
long_description.when: You just don't want to let go of winter

properties.name: Pop Up Park on Skye Hawk.

properties.short_description: Once you've conquered Start Park, Progression Parks are your next feat.

long_description.what: A first timer learning based terrain zone with small snow features built on a slight grade, small rollers and banked turns.
long_description.where: Ramshead Base Area - access via Progression Carpet 2
long_description.when: The next step up from Start Park

properties.name: Progression Park / & //

properties.short_description: A beginner freestyle terrain learning zone with ride on features at snow level

long_description.what: You'll find small and small-medium jumps, ride-on boxes and maybe a of couple low ride-on rails designed to be taken one feature at a time, so riders can hone their skills with slow control.
long_description.when: The next step up from Progression Parks / & //

properties.name: Progression Park ///

long_description.what: The inspiration for this zone came from Olympic gold medalist, Red Gerard's, own backyard rail garden just steps from his parents' back door. We're took a few tips from Red and brought this hike-style zone to the Woodward Mountain Park for all to enjoy.
long_description.who: Intermediate/advanced rail hounds. It's a hike park, too, so you can access it even if you don't have a regular lift ticket - just head to the ticket window and complete a risk waiver for a free hike-only ticket.
long_description.where: Lower Great Northern at the Ramshead Base Area
long_description.when: You're looking to slide some rails by any means necessary

properties.name: Red's Backyard on Lower Great Northern

long_description.what: The Start Park is aplayground on snow filled with featured terrain where first time skiers and riders start their journey as a Woodward athlete. Built and designed to effortlessly guide users through each section, the Start Park features slight contours in terrain aimed at controlling speed while gradually raising the bar, making for the smoothest transition in learning.
long_description.when: When you're ready to kick start your snow sliding experience, or learn the basics of terrain park riding.

properties.short_description: Freestyle riding started in the woods, and to the woods it returns with The Stash terrain park.

long_description.what: Developed in collaboration with Burton, The Stash is stacked with 65+ natural features including log rails, wall rides, rainbow trees and more. The entire zone is scattered throughout the woods under an alpine canopy, weaving on and off trail to create the ultimate all-terrain playground. The Stash is one of the most exceptional and organic terrain park experiences available.
long_description.when: You're looking to get back to nature

properties.name: The Stash
